Award.AwardTitle: ABI Innovation: Computational Methods for Bioacoustic Avian Species Monitoring
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on the development of a computational framework for intelligent monitoring of avian species from in situ audio recordings. The system will gather audio from a collection of microphones to automatically and adaptively infer spatio-temporal presence/absence and abundance for different bird species. The system will adaptively seek, request, and incorporate expert feedback to improve the ability to adjust to a new environment. By enabling the automatic collection of bird data at extremely fine temporal resolutions over relatively large spatial scales, we will address two questions of fundamental ecological and conservation importance (1) Can animal behavior buffer species against the effects of environmental changes? Specifically, do birds have the capacity to shift breeding territories in instances of rapid or extreme environmental changes (e.g., weather)? (2) How does loss and fragmentation of tropical forest alter the distributions of bird species?

This research will build upon the recently developed Multi-Instance Multi-Label framework from machine learning, and seek to adaptively and actively train species presence/absence and abundance estimation models with the goal of maximizing the learning efficiency while minimizing the human labeling efforts. The system's unique ability to actively identify and adapt to new species (and environments) will greatly reduce the overhead required to deploy and update the bioacoustic monitoring system. This project will provide computational innovations for studying biodiversity as a function of global habitat loss and climate change, contributing significant scientific knowledge about ecosystems and their responses to human activities. The project will also provide a new technology standard for collecting bird population data that could be deployed worldwide for monitoring a diverse and evolving set of species. Research-based education and training opportunities offered by this project will help prepare a new generation of researchers in the emerging area of Ecosystem Informatics at Oregon State University. Outreach activities will 1) involve high school educators in workshops organized by the Oregon Natural Resources Education (ONRE) program, 2) organize annual data challenges/competitions in association with international conferences and workshops, 3)recruit female undergraduates and K-12 students from under-represented groups to careers in computer science and engineering through REU programs. Further information on this project can be found at http://eecs.oregonstate.edu/research/bioacoustics/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Habitat loss and climate change are two of the primary causes of species decline worldwide. Birds have been used widely as biological indicators because they respond rapidly to change and are relatively easy to detect. Acquiring critical knowledge about the response of species to climate and land-use change necessitates the development of efficient and accurate estimates of species abundance and behavior in response to stressors. Data collection on bird species distribution and abundance has been plagued by problems of poor sample representation in remote regions, habitat sampling bias, imperfect detectability, and prohibitive costs of sampling over large spatial and temporal scales.  Technology including both video and audio plays an increasingly important role in facilitating fine resolution species monitoring. Developments in both signal processing and machine learning algorithms now pave the road for fully automated analysis. The complex nature of extracting ecologically meaningful information from bio-acoustic data necessitates the use of novel and advanced computational methods.  In this project, we collected bird audio data (song and wing flutter) over several years across multiple monitoring sites in Pacific Northwest and Costa Rica. We developed an automatic bioacoustics monitoring system that enables species classification and detection to assess bird species diversity, distribution and population sizes to examine hypotheses about the response of species both at species level and at individual levels to changes in environmental conditions.

 

Intellectual Merit:  The project supported two key thrusts: (i) an ecological thrust and (ii) a computational thrust. On the ecological side, we examined two key areas: the impacts of climate change on species distributions and the effect of tropical forest loss and fragmentation on bird pollinator distributions. Our results suggest that forest fragmentation and loss has significant impact on avian species distribution and richness in forested areas.

On the computational side, we developed species presence/absence prediction framework under the complex constraints associated with automatic in-situ recording. Additionally, we developed computational approaches for assessing bird biodiversity as well as novel methods for detection of previously unseen species.

 

Broader Impacts: The project resulted in a large dataset collected containing both bird song of multiple bird species as well as wing flutters of various hummingbird species. Our data as well as the computational tools are shared on our project website and can be used for researches in both the ecological community and the computational community. Additionally, the project promoted the training and learning of many students including postdocs, graduate and undergraduate students, and high school students, among them many are female and under-represented minority students.
